paragraphs.text: CIA torture report: Debunking the myths.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Last night, after months of delay, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence (SSCI) released a summary of their classified report on the Central Intelligence Agency's (CIA) post-9/11 Detention and Interrogation Programme
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That's government-speak for torture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was the first public accounting of what that programme actually entailed, and as one of the most controversial topics in Washington, is sure to create a political firestorm on both the left and the right, not to mention around the world, for many months to come
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In short
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it was shocking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was ugly
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It should lead no doubt to the reader that the programme was as wrong as it was useless
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And it can never be permitted to happen again
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The CIA's torture programme was authorised by then President George W Bush in August 2002
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: giving them broad discretion in the use of harsh interrogation techniques that included waterboarding, sleep deprivation, hypothermia, stress positions, abdomen strikes, slapping and forced shaking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its stated purpose was to solicit actionable intelligence that might save American lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In effect, it gave carte blanche for interrogators to do pretty much anything they wanted from a laundry list of macabre techniques to extract that information
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To those behind the programme, the moral question was perversely inconsequential
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as they all too readily adopted the Machiavellian philosophy of "the end justifies the means"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In methodical fashion, SSCI laid out its case through 20 findings and conclusions, followed by detailed supporting chapters tying them all together
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Abysmal failure
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Nearly 500 pages in length, it was a mere, yet chilling, fraction of the overall report
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which will remain classified
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the message was clear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The torture programme, despite what its supporters claimed at the time, and continue to do so even now, was an abysmal failure and disgrace for the US
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In its very first finding, which set the stage for what was to follow
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: SSCI concluded the use of torture was not an "effective means of acquiring intelligence or gaining cooperation from detainees"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And most disturbingly, right from the beginning, CIA officers routinely called into question the programme's effectiveness in producing accurate intelligence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: their leadership turned a blind eye to those concerns, ignoring numerous internal critiques, criticisms and objections from those charged with carrying out the grisly day-to-day operations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There were even instances when interrogators were ordered to continue torturing certain detainees who they had already assessed as being cooperative
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This is what we call a crisis in leadership - both at the CIA and at the highest levels of the Bush Administration
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Incredibly, of the 20 examples most often used by the CIA to show how successful their torture programme was, all were determined to be fundamentally wrong or misleading
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Case in point
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In their representations to the White House, National Security Council, Department of Justice, Congress and the American people, the CIA often referred to Abu Zubaydah as "proof" that those methods provided real, actionable intelligence that saved American lives
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Zubaydah, a senior al-Qaeda figure, was captured in Pakistan in March 2002
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Several months later
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: after the torture programme was authorised
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: he was subjected to numerous and repeated torture techniques, to include being waterboarded 83 times
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: According to former Bush Administration and CIA officials involved in the programme at the time, Zubaydah - as a direct result of his being waterboarded - not only provided information that allowed the FBI to disrupt the Jose Padilla "Dirty Bomb Plot" in Chicago, but also identified Khalid Sheikh Mohammed as the mastermind behind the 9/11 attacks
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: There' s only one problem with that story
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It wasn't true
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to the SSCI report, the FBI actually obtained that information from Zubaydah through legal interrogation techniques between March and June 2002, and provided it to the CIA months before he was ever subjected to waterboarding or any other torture techniques
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: According to the FBI interrogators, they had developed a rapport with Zubaydah
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: who was cooperating with them
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And yet, the CIA decided to subject him to torture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Maybe Zubaydah repeated that information as a result of waterboarding
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the official record reflects that it certainly wasn't the first time the CIA ever heard about it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And that's pretty much it when it comes to "actionable intelligence" gained through the CIA's use of torture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: None
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Nada
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Zip
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Seriously?
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: But it gets worse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Beginning with Zubaydah, the first CIA detainee to undergo torture, and continuing on with numerous others, the techniques went on for days or weeks at a time
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There were physical beatings, mock executions, sleep deprivations for days at a time while standing with hands chained above their heads, and threats to sexually assault or kill detainees' family members
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: One detainee even died, apparently of hypothermia, after being chained nearly naked to a cement floor
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Reading the report, one has to ask how the US, or any country for that matter could morally justify what was done
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It can't
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The final finding and conclusion was an understatement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: in that the CIA's torture programme "damaged the United States' standing in the world"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And that's something the US isn't going to get over any time soon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a longtime global leader in human rights issues, particularly on the subject of torture, the US has lost its moral credibility on the world stage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Law of the land
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The first step in ending the torture programme was accomplished in 2009
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: US President Barack Obama signed an executive order banning it shortly after taking office
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That's the law of the land in the US right now
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when Obama leaves office in 2016
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: there' s nothing to stop his successor from authorising it again
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Except, of course, the court of public opinion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which is why the release of this report was so important
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In a recent Pew Research report, half the US public polled thought torture could be justified sometimes or even often
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The second step happened last night with SSCI's public release of their report summary
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No doubt, those who are still in favour the torture programme, particularly the former Bush Administration and the CIA officials closely involved with it, will aggressively refute the facts laid out in SSCI's report
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Let them
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Then, it's time to have a frank and informed discussion on the whole torture issue, separating the facts from the myths
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The American public and its leaders need to ask themselves if torture is how they really want to be defined
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Does the end really justify the means?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After reading the report, one would have to wonder how it could
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Torture is wrong, plain and simple
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The US needs to reject it outright now
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while the report, in all its shocking and macabre detail, is fresh in the public's mind
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Otherwise
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they'll find themselves going back down that path again the next time fear and panic take hold
paragraphs.label: assumption
